qas.question: How far does a glacier have to move to cause glacial earthquakes?
How high can the seismic magnitude be of a glacial earthquake?
Are Greenland's glacial earthquakes increasing or decreasing as time goes on?
During which months do glacial earthquakes peak in Greenland?
In what year were twice as many glacial earthquakes seen than in any other year in Greenland?
What occurs where glaciers are moving slower than 1 km per day?
What peaks Every July in Iceland?
What is causing a decrease in Greenlands glacial earthquakes?

plausible_answers.text: The number of glacial earthquakes in Greenland

qas.question: What has been decreasing over time?

context: In glaciated areas where the glacier moves faster than <a0_0>one km per year<a0_0/>, <b5_0>glacial earthquakes<b5_0/> occur. These are large scale temblors that have seismic magnitudes as high as <a1_0>6.1<a1_0/>. <b6_0><b8_0>The number of glacial earthquakes<b6_0/> in Greenland<b8_0/> peaks every year in <a3_0>July, August and September<a3_0/> and is <a2_0>increasing<a2_0/> over time. In a study using data from January 1993 through October 2005, more events were detected every year since 2002, and twice as many events were recorded in <a4_0>2005<a4_0/> as there were in any other year. This increase in the numbers of <b7_0>glacial earthquakes<b7_0/> in Greenland may be a response to global warming.
